Indicator: Poverty headcount ratio at $2.15/day (2017 PPP, %)
New: Modification: New global poverty line for low-income countries
Reference: Cuaresma, J. C., Fengler, W., Kharas, H., Bekhtiar, K., Brottrager, M., & Hofer, M. (2019). Will the Sustainable Development Goals be fulfilled? Assessing present and future global poverty. Palgrave Communications, 4(1), 29. World Poverty Clock available from http://worldpoverty.io/
Description: Estimated percentage of the population that is living under the poverty threshold of US$2.15 a day. Estimated using historical estimates of the income distribution, projections of population changes by age and educational attainment, and GDP projections.
Imputation: Data was not reported for those countries where no survey data was available. For countries without survey data whose estimates were more than half the median poverty rate and whose life expectancy was less than the median, the data point was retained.

Indicator: Poverty headcount ratio at $3.65/day (2017 PPP, %)
New: Modification: New global poverty line for lower-middle-income countries
Reference: Cuaresma, J. C., Fengler, W., Kharas, H., Bekhtiar, K., Brottrager, M., & Hofer, M. (2019). Will the Sustainable Development Goals be fulfilled? Assessing present and future global poverty. Palgrave Communications, 4(1), 29. World Poverty Clock available from http://worldpoverty.io/
Description: Estimated percentage of the population that is living under the poverty threshold of US$3.65 a day. Estimated using historical estimates of the income distribution, projections of population changes by age and educational attainment, and GDP projections.
Imputation: Data was not reported for those countries where no survey data was available. For countries without survey data whose estimates were more than half the median poverty rate and whose life expectancy was less than the median, the data point was retained.

Indicator: Poverty rate after taxes and transfers (%)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The share of the population whose incomes fall below half the median disposable income for the entire population. The income threshold for relative poverty changes over time with changes in median disposable income.

Indicator: Prevalence of undernourishment (%)
Reference: FAO (2023). Prevalence of undernourishment (% of population). Food and Agriculture Organization, Rome. Available from: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SN.ITK.DEFC.ZS
Description: The percentage of the population whose food intake is insufficient to meet dietary energy requirements for a minimum of one year. Dietary energy requirements are defined as the amount of dietary energy required by an individual to maintain body functions, health and normal activity. Due to uncertainty in the estimates, the lowest value FAO attributes to countries is 2.5%. We therefore assume 2.5% in all high-income countries with missing data.
Imputation: Due to uncertainty in the estimates, the lowest value FAO attributes to countries is 2.5%. We therefore assume 2.5% in all high-income countries with missing data.

Indicator: Prevalence of stunting in children under 5 years of age (%)
Reference: UNICEF, et al. (2023). Prevalence of stunting, height for age (% of children under 5). United Nations Children's Fund, New York. Available from: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SH.STA.STNT.ZS
Description: The percentage of children up to the age of 5 years that are stunted, measured as the percentage that fall below minus two standard deviations from the median height for their age, according to the WHO Child Growth Standards. UNICEF et al. (2016) report an average prevalence of stunting in high-income countries of 2.58%. We assumed this value for high-income countries with missing data.
Imputation: UNICEF et al. (2016) report an average prevalence of stunting in high-income countries of 2.58%. We assumed this value for high-income countries with missing data. Modeled estimates from the IHME are used for calculating trend estimations due to missing data in the series from UNICEF.

Indicator: Prevalence of wasting in children under 5 years of age (%)
Reference: UNICEF, et al. (2023). Prevalence of wasting, weight for height (% of children under 5). United Nations Children's Fund, New York. Available from: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SH.STA.WAST.ZS
Description: The percentage of children up to the age of 5 years whose weight falls below minus two standard deviations from the median weight for their age, according to the WHO Child Growth Standards. UNICEF et al. (2016) report an average prevalence of wasting in high-income countries of 0.75%. We assumed this value for high-income countries with missing data.
Imputation: UNICEF et al. (2016) report an average prevalence of wasting in high-income countries of 0.75%. We assumed this value for high-income countries with missing data. Modeled estimates from the IHME are used for calculating trend estimations due to missing data in the series from UNICEF.

Indicator: Prevalence of obesity, BMI ≥ 30 (% of adult population)
Reference: WHO (2023) Global Health Observatory. Obesity (age- standardized estimate). World Health Organization, Geneva. Available from: http://apps.who.int/gho/data/view.main.CTRY2450A?lang=en
Description: The percentage of the adult population that has a body mass index (BMI) of 30kg/m² or higher, based on measured height and weight.

Indicator: Human Trophic Level (best 2-3 worst)
Source:
Bonhommeau et al. (2013) 
data updated to 2017
Reference: Bonhommeau, S., Dubroca, L., Le Pape, O., Barde, J., Kaplan, D. M., Chassot, E., & Nieblas, A. E. (2013). Eating up the world’s food web and the human trophic level. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 110(51), 20617-20620. Available from: https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1305827110
Description: Trophic levels are a measure of the energy intensity of diet composition and reflect the relative amounts of plants as opposed to animals eaten in each country. A higher trophic level represents a greater level of consumption of energy-intensive animals.

Indicator: Cereal yield (tonnes per hectare of harvested land)
Reference: FAO (2023). Cereal Yield (kg per hectare). Food and Agriculture Organization, Rome. Available from: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/AG.YLD.CREL.KG
Description: Cereal yield, measured as tonnes per hectare of harvested land. Production data on cereals relate to crops harvested for dry grain only and excludes crops harvested for hay or green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing.
Computation: This indicator is obtained by dividing cereal yield expressed in kilograms by 1000 to convert into tonnes of cereal produced per hectare of harvested land.

Indicator: Sustainable Nitrogen Management Index (best 0-1.41 worst)
Reference: Zhang, X., & Davidson, E. (2019). Sustainable Nitrogen Management Index. Earth and Space Science Open Archive. Available from: https://doi.org/10.1002/essoar.10501111.1
Description: The Sustainable Nitrogen Management Index (SNMI) is a one-dimensional ranking score that combines two efficiency measures in crop production: Nitrogen use efficiency (NUE) and land use efficiency (crop yield).

Indicator: Yield gap closure (% of potential yield)
Reference: Global Yield Gap Atlas (2015). A joint initiative of Wageningen University & Research and University of Nebraska-Lincoln. Available from: http://www.yieldgap.org
Description: A country's yield expressed as a percentage of its potential yield in the three annual crops using the most land area, weighted for the relative importance of each crop in terms of surface area.
Computation: This indicator is obtained by computing the Yield gap (%) as the average of three rainfed-crops' yield gap (wheat, maize and barley), weighted by their respective share in the total crop and livestocks land use. The Yield gap closure (%) is then calculated by substracting the average yield gap from 100.

Indicator: Exports of hazardous pesticides (tonnes per million population)
Reference: FAO (2023). Trade in hazardous peseticides. Food and Agriculture Organization, Rome. Available from: http://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/RT/metadata
Description: Exports of pesticides deemed hazardous to human health, standardized by population. Due to volatility, the calculation uses the average value over the last 5 years.
Computation: This indicator is computed as a 5 years-average of exports of hazardous pesticides expressed in tonnes, divided by total population and multiplied by 1 000 000 to convert into tonnes per million population.

Indicator: Maternal mortality rate (per 100,000 live births)
Reference: WHO, et al. (2023). Maternal mortality ratio (modeled estimate, per 100,000 live births). World Health Organization, Geneva. Available from: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SH.STA.MMRT
Description: The estimated number of women, between the age of 15 and 49, who die from pregnancy-related causes while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, per 100,000 live births.

Indicator: Neonatal mortality rate (per 1,000 live births)
Reference: UNICEF, et al. (2023). Mortality rate, neonatal (per 1,000 live births). United Nations Children's Fund, New York. Available from: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SH.DYN.NMRT
Description: The number of newborn infants (neonates) who die before reaching 28 days of age, per 1,000 live births.

Indicator: Mortality rate, under-5 (per 1,000 live births)
Reference: UNICEF, et al. (2023). Mortality rate, under-5 (per 1,000 live births). United Nations Children's Fund, New York. Available from: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SH.DYN.MORT
Description: The probability that a newborn baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year, per 1,000 live births.

Indicator: Incidence of tuberculosis (per 100,000 population)
Reference: WHO (2023) Global Health Observatory. Incidence of tuberculosis (per 100,000 people). World Health Organization, Geneva. Available from: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SH.TBS.INCD
Description: The estimated rate of new and relapse cases of tuberculosis each year, expressed per 100,000 people. All forms of tuberculosis are included, including cases of people living with HIV.

Indicator: New HIV infections (per 1,000 uninfected population)
Reference: UNAIDS (2023). Aidsinfo. HIV incidence per 1000 population (15-49). Joint United Nations Programme on HIV and AIDS, Geneva. Available from: http://aidsinfo.unaids.org?did=55da49cd64e925b94e70b0ce&r=world&t=2023&tb=d&bt=dnli&ts=0,0&tr=world&aid=5970eccef7341ed11f26de5d&sav=Population: All ages&tl=2
Description: Number of people newly infected with HIV per 1,000 uninfected population.

Indicator: Age-standardized death rate due to cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory disease in adults aged 30–70 years (%)
Reference: WHO (2023) Global Health Observatory. Age-standardized death rate due to cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes, and chronic respiratory disease in populations age 30–70 years, per 100 000 population. World Health Organization, Geneva. Available from: https://apps.who.int/gho/data/view.main.GSWCAH21v
Description: The probability of dying between the ages of 30 and 70 years from cardiovascular diseases, cancer, diabetes or chronic respiratory diseases, defined as the percent of 30-year-old-people who would die before their 70th birthday from these diseases, assuming current mortality rates at every age and that individuals would not die from any other cause of death (e.g. injuries or HIV/AIDS).

Indicator: Age-standardized death rate attributable to household air pollution and ambient air pollution (per 100,000 population)
Reference: WHO (2023) Global Health Observatory. Age-standardized death rate attributable to household air pollution and ambient air pollution, per 100 000 population. World Health Organization, Geneva. Available from: https://apps.who.int/gho/data/view.main.GSWCAH37v
Description: Mortality rate that is attributable to the joint effects of fuels used for cooking indoors and ambient outdoor air pollution.

Indicator: Traffic deaths (per 100,000 population)
Reference: WHO (2023) Global Health Observatory. Road traffic deaths. World Health Organization, Geneva. Available from: http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.A997
Description: Estimated number of fatal road traffic injuries per 100,000 people.

Indicator: Life expectancy at birth (years)
Reference: WHO (2023) Global Health Observatory. Life expectancy and healthy life expectancy. World Health Organization, Geneva. Available from: http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.688
Description: The average number of years that a newborn could expect to live, if he or she were to pass through life exposed to the sex- and age-specific death rates prevailing at the time of his or her birth, for a specific year, in a given country, territory, or geographic area.

Indicator: Adolescent fertility rate (births per 1,000 females aged 15 to 19)
Reference: WHO (2023) Global Health Observatory. Adolescent birth rate. World Health Organization, Geneva. Available from: https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/indicators/indicator-details/GHO/adolescent-birth-rate-(per-1000-women-aged-15-19-years)
Description: The number of births per 1,000 females between the age of 15 and 19.

Indicator: Births attended by skilled health personnel (%)
Reference: UNICEF (2023). Births attended by skilled health staff (% of total). United Nations Children's Fund, New York. Available from: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SH.STA.BRTC.ZS
Description: The percentage of births attended by personnel trained to give the necessary supervision, care, and advice to women during pregnancy, labor, and the postpartum period, to conduct deliveries on their own, and to care for newborns.

Indicator: Surviving infants who received 2 WHO-recommended vaccines (%)
Reference: WHO, UNICEF (2023). Immunization Coverage. World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Geneva and New York. Available from: http://data.unicef.org/topic/child-health/immunization/
Description: Estimated national routine immunization coverage of infants, expressed as the percentage of surviving infants, children under the age of 12 months, who received two WHO-recommended vaccines (3rd dose of DTP and 1st dose of measles). Calculated as the minimum value between the percentage of infants who have received the 3rd dose of DTP and the percentage who have received the 1st dose of measles.
Computation: This indicator is computed as the minimum value between the percentage of surviving infants who received the DTP3 vaccine and the percentage that received the MCV1 vaccine.

Indicator: Universal health coverage (UHC) index of service coverage (worst 0-100 best)
Reference: WHO (2023) Global Health Observatory. Tracking universal health coverage: 2023 Global Monitoring Report. World Health Organization, Geneva. Available from: http://www.who.int/healthinfo/universal_health_coverage/report/2023/en/
Description: Coverage of essential health services (defined as the average coverage of essential services based on tracer interventions that include reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health, infectious diseases, non-communicable diseases and service capacity and access, among the general and the most disadvantaged population). The indicator is an index reported on a unitless scale of 0 to 100, which is computed as the geometric mean of 14 tracer indicators of health service coverage.

Indicator: Subjective well-being (average ladder score, worst 0-10 best)
Reference: Gallup (2023). Gallup World Poll. https://www.gallup.com/analytics/318875/global-research.aspx
Description: Subjective self-evaluation of life, where respondents are asked to evaluate where they feel they stand on a ladder where 0 represents the worst possible life and 10 the best possible life.

Indicator: Gap in life expectancy at birth among regions (years)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: Difference between maximum and minimum regional life expectancy at birth among regions.
Computation: The gap in life expectancy at birth among regions is computed as the difference between the years of life expectancy at birth in the country's region with the highest value and the years of life expectancy at birth in the country's region with the lowest value.

Indicator: Gap in self-reported health status by income (percentage points)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: Gap in percentage of people who perceive their health status as good or very good between the poorest 20% and the richest 20% of the population.
Computation: The gap in self-reported health by income (in percentage points) is computed as the difference between the percentage of individuals - among the richest 20% of the population - perceiving their health status as good or very good, and the percentage of individuals - among the poorest 20% -  that perceive their health status as good or very good.

Indicator: Daily smokers (% of population aged 15 and over)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The percentage of the population aged 15 years and older who are reported to smoke daily.

Indicator: Participation rate in pre-primary organized learning (% of children aged 4 to 6)
Reference: UNESCO (2023). UIS.Stat. United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Paris. Available from: http://sdg4-data.uis.unesco.org/
Description: Participation rate in organized learning one year before the official primary entry age measured by the adjusted net enrollment rate in organized learning.

Indicator: Net primary enrollment rate (%)
Reference: UNESCO (2023). UIS.Stat. Net enrolment rate, primary, both sexes (%). United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Paris. Available from: http://data.uis.unesco.org/
Description: The percentage of children of the official school age population who are enrolled in primary education.

Indicator: Lower secondary completion rate (%)
Reference: UNESCO (2023). UIS.Stat. Lower secondary completion rate, total (% of relevant age group). United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Paris. Available from: http://data.uis.unesco.org/
Description: Lower secondary education completion rate measured as the gross intake ratio to the last grade of lower secondary education (general and pre-vocational). It is calculated as the number of new entrants in the last grade of lower secondary education, regardless of age, divided by the population at the entrance age for the last grade of lower secondary education.
Imputation: OECD enrollment data (for population from 6 to 14 years) was imputed for OECD countries with missing data in the UNESCO database. Data available from: https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=EAG_ENRL_RATE_AGE#

Indicator: Literacy rate (% of population aged 15 to 24)
Reference: UNESCO (2023). UIS.Stat. Youth literacy rate, population 15-24 years, both sexes (%). United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Paris. Available from: http://data.uis.unesco.org/
Description: The percentage of youth, aged 15 to 24, who can both read and write a short simple statement on everyday life with understanding.

Indicator: Tertiary educational attainment (% of population aged 25 to 34)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The percentage of the population, aged 25 to 34, who have completed tertiary education.

Indicator: PISA score (worst 0-600 best)
Reference: OECD (2023). PISA Database. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://pisadataexplorer.oecd.org/ide/idepisa/dataset.aspx.
Description: National scores in the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA), an internationally standardized assessment that is administered to 15-year-olds in schools. It assesses how far students near the end of compulsory education have acquired some of the knowledge and skills that are essential for full participation in society. Country PISA scores for reading, mathematics, and science were averaged to obtain an overall PISA score.

Indicator: Variation in science performance explained by socio-economic status (%)
Reference: OECD (2023). PISA Database. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://pisadataexplorer.oecd.org/ide/idepisa/dataset.aspx.
Description: Percentage of variation in science performance explained by students' socio-economic status.

Indicator: Underachievers in science (% of 15-year-olds)
Reference: OECD (2023). PISA Database. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://pisadataexplorer.oecd.org/ide/idepisa/dataset.aspx.
Description: Percentage of students with a performance in science below level 2 (less than 409.54 score points).

Indicator: Demand for family planning satisfied by modern methods (% of females aged 15 to 49)
Reference: UNDESA (2023). Population Division. Proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15-49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods (% of women aged 15-49 years). World Contraceptive Use 2023 (POP/DB/CP/Rev2023). United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, New York. Available from: https://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/publications/dataset/contraception/wcu2023.asp
Description: The percentage of women of reproductive age whose demand for family planning has been met using modern methods of contraception.
Imputation: For countries missing administrative data, we impute modeled estimates from UNDESA Population Division  (https://www.un.org/development/desa/pd/data/family-planning-indicators).

Indicator: Modeled estimate: Demand for family planning satisfied by any modern method (% of females aged 15 to 49)
Reference: UNDESA (2023). Family Planning – Model. United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, New York. Available from: http://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/theme/family- planning/cp_model.shtml

Indicator: Ratio of female-to-male mean years of education received (%)
Reference: UNDP (2023). Human Development Report 2021-22: Uncertain Times, Unsettled Lives: Shaping our Future in a Transforming World. New York.
Description: The mean years of education received by women aged 25 and older divided by the mean years of education received by men aged 25 and older.

Indicator: Ratio of female-to-male labor force participation rate (%)
Reference: ILO (2023). Ratio of female to male labor force participation rate (%) (modeled ILO estimate). International Labour Organization, Geneva. Available from: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SL.TLF.CACT.FM.ZS
Description: Modeled estimate of the proportion of the female population aged 15 years and older that is economically active, divided by the same proportion for men.

Indicator: Seats held by women in national parliament (%)
Reference: IPU (2023). Proportion of seats held by women in national parliaments (%). Inter-Parliamentary Union, Geneva. Available from: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SG.GEN.PARL.ZS
Description: The number of seats held by women in single or lower chambers of national parliaments, expressed as a percentage of all occupied seats. Seats refer to the number of parliamentary mandates, or the number of members of parliament.

Indicator: Gender wage gap (% of male median wage)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The difference between male and female median wages of full-time employees and those self-employed, divided by the male median wage.

Indicator: Population using at least basic drinking water services (%)
Reference: WHO, UNICEF (2023). WHO / UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme: Data & estimates. People using at least basic drinking water services (% of population). World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Geneva and New York. Available from: https://washdata.org/data
Description: The percentage of the population using at least a basic drinking water service, such as drinking water from an improved source, provided that the collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a round trip, including queuing.

Indicator: Population using at least basic sanitation services (%)
Reference: WHO, UNICEF (2023). WHO / UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme: Data & estimates. People using at least basic sanitation services (% of population). World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Geneva and New York. Available from: https://washdata.org/data
Description: The percentage of the population using at least a basic sanitation service, such as an improved sanitation facility that is not shared with other households.

Indicator: Freshwater withdrawal (% of available freshwater resources)
Reference: FAO (2023). AQUASTAT. Level of water stress: freshwater withdrawal as a proportion of available freshwater resources (%). Food and Agriculture Organization, Rome. Available from: http://www.fao.org/nr/water/aquastat/data/query/index.html?lang=en
Description: The level of water stress: freshwater withdrawal as a proportion of available freshwater resources is the ratio between total freshwater withdrawn by all major sectors and total renewable freshwater resources, after taking into account environmental water requirements. Main sectors, as defined by ISIC standards, include agriculture, forestry and fishing, manufacturing, electricity industry, and services. This indicator is also known as water withdrawal intensity.

Indicator: Anthropogenic wastewater that receives treatment (%)
Reference: Wendling, Z. A., Emerson, J. W., Esty, D. C., Levy, M. A., de Sherbinin, A., et al. (2018). 2018 Environmental Performance Index. New Haven, CT: Yale Center for Environmental Law & Policy. Available from: http://epi.yale.edu.
Description: The proportion of wastewater that undergoes at least primary treatment in each country, multiplied by the proportion of the population connected to a wastewater collection system.
Imputation: Malta's datapoint was imputed from UN Stats: https://unstats.un.org/unsd/envstats/Questionnaires/2019/Tables/Population%20connected%20to%20wastewater%20treatment.xlsx

Indicator: Scarce water consumption embodied in imports (m3 H2O eq/capita)
Reference: UNEP (2023). SCP-HAT database v2.0. http://scp-hat.lifecycleinitiative.org/methods/. UN Life Cycle Initiative, UN One Planet Network, UN International Resource Panel. Paris
Description: Water scarcity is measured as water consumption weighted by scarcity indices. In order to incorporate water scarcity into the virtual water flow calculus, water use entries are weighted so that they reflect the scarcity of the water being used.  The weight used is a measure of water withdrawals as a percentage of the existing local renewable freshwater resources.
Computation: This indicator is calculated as the sum of water stress from agriculture and non-agricultural activities (expressed in million m3 H2Oeq), which is then multiplied by 1 000 000 to express it in m3 H2Oeq. It is then divided by the country's total population to express it in m3/capita.

Indicator: Population using safely managed water services (%)
Reference: WHO, UNICEF (2023). WHO / UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme: Data & estimates. World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Geneva and New York. Available from: https://washdata.org/data
Description: The percentage of the population using a safely managed drinking water service. A safely managed drinking water service is one where people use an "improved" source meeting three criteria: it is accessible on premises, water is available when needed, and the water supplied is free from contamination. Improved sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water by nature of their design and construction.
Imputation: The data point of New Zealand was imputed to Australia.

Indicator: Population using safely managed sanitation services (%)
Reference: WHO, UNICEF (2023). WHO / UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme: Data & estimates. World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Geneva and New York. Available from: https://washdata.org/data
Description: The percentage of the population using safely managed sanitation services. Safely managed sanitation services are "improved" sanitation facilities that are not shared with other households, and where the excreta produced should either be treated and disposed of in situ, stored temporarily and then emptied, transported and treated off-site, or transported through a sewer with wastewater and then treated off-site. Improved sanitation facilities are those designed to hygienically separate excreta from human contact.

Indicator: Population with access to electricity (%)
Reference: IEA, IRENA, UNSD, WB, WHO (2023). Tracking SDG7: The Energy Progress Report, 2023
Description: The percentage of the population who has access to electricity.

Indicator: Population with access to clean fuels and technology for cooking (%)
Reference: WHO (2023) Global Health Observatory. Proportion of population with access to clean fuels and technology for cooking; Available from: https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/indicators/indicator-details/GHO/gho-phe-primary-reliance-on-clean-fuels-and-technologies-proportion
Description: The percentage of the population primarily using clean cooking fuels and technologies for cooking. Under WHO guidelines, kerosene is excluded from clean cooking fuels.

Indicator: CO₂ emissions from fuel combustion per total electricity output (MtCO₂/TWh)
Reference: IEA (2019). CO2 Emissions From Fuel Combustion 2019. International Energy Agency, Paris. Available from: https://www.iea.org/reports/co2-emissions-from-fuel-combustion-2019
Description: A measure of the carbon intensity of energy production, calculated by dividing CO₂ emissions from the combustion of fuel by electricity output. The data are reported in Megatonnes per billion kilowatt hours.
Computation: This indicator was calculated by dividing total CO2 emissions from fuel combustion for electricity and heat (MtCO2) over Electricity output (TWh).

Indicator: Renewable energy share in total final energy consumption (%)
Reference: IEA, IRENA, UNSD, WB, WHO (2023). Tracking SDG7: The Energy Progress Report, 2023. Available from: https://trackingsdg7.esmap.org/time
Description: The share of renewable energy in the total final energy consumption. Renewable energy includes hydro, solid biofuels, liquid biofuels, biogases, modern biomass, wind, solar, geothermal, tide/wave/oceans and renewable municipal waste. It does not include traditional biomass — local solid biomass resources (e.g. wood, charcoal, dung, agricultural residues) used in low-income households that do not have access to modern cooking fuels or technologies.

Indicator: Adjusted GDP growth (%)
Reference: World Bank (2023). GDP per capita, PPP (current international $). World Bank, Washington, D.C. Available from: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.CD
Description: The growth rate of GDP adjusted to income levels (where rich countries are expected to grow less) and expressed relative to the average growth rate of high income countries. The growth rate over the last 3-year period (t-3 to t) was calculated where  GRa=(At/At-3)^(1/3)-1 and where GRa is the growth rate for country A and At is the GDP per capita data for the year t in country A. Then our adjustment is as follows : ADJa= [GRa-(GRhic - 0,015*log(At-3/hict-3))] * 100, where GRhic is the average growth rate of high-income countries and hict-3 is the average GDP per capita of high-income countries three years ago.
Computation: The growth rate over the last 3-year period (t-3 to t) was calculated where  GRa=(At/At-3)^(1/3)-1 and where GRa is the growth rate for country A and At is the GDP per capita data for the year t in country A. Then our adjustment is as follows : ADJa= [GRa-(GRhic - 0,015*log(At-3/hict-3))] * 100, where GRhic is the average growth rate of high-income countries and hict-3 is the average GDP per capita of high-income countries three years ago.

Indicator: Victims of modern slavery (per 1,000 population)
Reference: Walk Free Foundation (2018). Global Slavery Index 2018. Walk Free Foundation, Broadway Nedlands, Australia. Available from: https://www.globalslaveryindex.org/
Description: Estimation of the number of people in modern slavery. Modern slavery is defined as people in forced labor or forced marriage. It is calculated based on standardized surveys and Multiple Systems Estimation (MSE).
Imputation: We assume missing data points for those countries in which the Walk Free Foundation's methodology is not based on any empirical estimate due to survey unavailability.

Indicator: Adults with an account at a bank or other financial institution or with a mobile-money-service provider (% of population aged 15 or over)
Reference: Global Findex Database (2022). World Bank, Washington, D.C. Available from: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/FX.OWN.TOTL.ZS
Description: The percentage of adults, 15 years and older, who report having an account (by themselves or with someone else) at a bank or another type of financial institution, or who have personally used a mobile money service within the past 12 months.

Indicator: Unemployment rate (% of total labor force, ages 15+)
Reference: ILO (2023). Unemployment, total (% of total labor force) (modeled ILO estimate). International Labour Organization, Geneva. Available from: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SL.UEM.TOTL.ZS
Description: Modeled estimate of the share of the labor force that is without work but is available and actively seeking employment. The indicator reflects the inability of an economy to generate employment for people who want to work but are not doing so.

Indicator: Fundamental labor rights are effectively guaranteed (worst 0–1 best)
Reference: The World justice project : Rule of Law Index 2022. Washington, D.C: The World Justice Project, 2022. Available from: https://worldjusticeproject.org/rule-of-law-index/
Description: Measures the effective enforcement of fundamental labor rights, including freedom of association and the right to collective bargaining, the absence of discrimination with respect to employment, and freedom from forced labor and child labor.

Indicator: Fatal work-related accidents embodied in imports (per 100,000 population)
Source:
Alsamawi et al. (2017) 
data updated to 2018
Reference: Alsamawi, A., Murray, J., Lenzen, M., & Reyes, R. C. (2017). Trade in occupational safety and health: Tracing the embodied human and economic harm in labour along the global supply chain. Journal of cleaner production, 147, 187-196.
Description: The number of fatal work-related accidents associated with imported goods. Calculated using extensions to a multiregional input-output table.
Computation: The number of fatal accidents that happen overseas for domestic consumption is divided by total population and multiplied by 100 000.

Indicator: Victims of modern slavery embodied in imports (per 100,000 population)
Reference: Shilling, H.-J., Wiedmann, T., & Malik, A. (2021). Modern slavery footprints in global supply chains. Journal of Industrial Ecology, 25(7), 1518-1528
Description: Victims of forced labor embodied in supply chains. Calculated using a multi-regional input-output table (Gloria) extended with a slavery satellite account
Computation: This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of victims of forced labor by total population and multiplying by 100 000.

Indicator: Employment-to-population ratio (%)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The ratio of the employed to the working age population. Employed people are those aged 15 or older who were in paid employment or self-employed during a specified period. The working age population refers to people aged 15 to 64.

Indicator: Youth not in employment, education or training (NEET) (% of population aged 15 to 29)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The percentage of young people who are not in employment, education or training (NEET). Education includes part-time or full-time education but excludes those in non-formal education and in educational activities of very short duration. Employment is defined according to the ILO Guidelines and covers all those who have been in paid work for at least one hour in the reference week or were temporarily absent from such work.

Indicator: Rural population with access to all-season roads (%)
Source: SDSN (2023), based on Workman, R. & McPherson, K., TRL (2019)
Reference: SDSN (2023) Rural Access Index 2022 by Country. Based on Workman, R. & McPherson, K., TRL (2019). Measuring Rural Access Using New Technologies: Supplemental Guidelines. ReCAP GEN2033D. London: ReCAP for DFID.
Description: Proportion of the rural population that lives within 2 km of an all-season road. An all-season road is one that is motorable throughout the year but may be temporarily unavailable during inclement weather.

Indicator: Population using the internet (%)
Reference: ITU (2023). World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators database. International Telecommunication Union, Geneva. Available from: http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Pages/publications/wtid.aspx
Description: The percentage of the population who used the Internet from any location in the last three months. Access could be via a fixed or mobile network.

Indicator: Mobile broadband subscriptions (per 100 population)
Reference: ITU (2023). World Telecommunication/ICT Indicators database. International Telecommunication Union, Geneva.
Description: The number of mobile broadband subscriptions per 100 population. Mobile broadband subscriptions refer to subscriptions to mobile cellular networks with access to data communications (e.g. the Internet) at broadband speeds, irrespective of the device used to access the internet.

Indicator: Logistics Performance Index: Quality of trade and transport-related infrastructure (worst 1-5 best)
Reference: World Bank (2018). 2018 Logistics Performance Index (LPI). World Bank, Washington, D.C. Available from: http://lpi.worldbank.org/international/global
Description: Survey-based average assessment of the quality of trade and transport related infrastructure, e.g. ports, roads, railroads and information technology, on a scale from 1 (worst) to 5 (best).

Indicator: The Times Higher Education Universities Ranking: Average score of top 3 universities (worst 0-100 best)
Reference: Times Higher Education (2023). World University Rankings 2023. https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings
Description: The average score of the top three universities in each country that are listed in the global top 1,000 universities in the world. For countries with at least one university on the list, only the score of the ranked university was taken into account.  When a university score was missing in the Times Higher Education World University Ranking, an indicator from the Global Innovation Index on the top 3 universities in Quacquarelli Symonds (QS) University Ranking was used as a source when available.
Imputation: We impute values from the Global Innovation Index's indicator on university scores in the QS University Rankings for countries with missing data. We assumed a value of 0 for countries with no universities in the rankings.
Computation: This indicator is calculated as the average score of the top three universities in each country that are listed in the global top 1,000 universities in the world, expressed as 0–100. For countries with at least one university on the list, only the score of the ranked university was taken into account. Whenever a university score was missing in the Times Higher Education World University Ranking, an indicator from the Global Innovation Index on the top 3 universities in Quacquarelli Symonds (QS) University Ranking, was used as a source when available, and countries who had no universities present in the rankings received a score of 0.

Indicator: Articles published in academic journals (per 1,000 population)
Reference: SCImago Journal & Country Rank (2023). Available from http://www.scimagojr.com
Description: Number of citable documents published by a journal in the three previous years (selected year documents are excluded). Exclusively articles, reviews and conference papers are considered.
Computation: This indicator is computed as the number of citable documents published in a journal divided by total population and multiplied by 1000.

Indicator: Expenditure on research and development (% of GDP)
Reference: UNESCO (2023). UIS.Stat. United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Paris. Available from: http://data.uis.unesco.org/
Description: Gross domestic expenditure on scientific research and experimental development (R&D) expressed as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product (GDP). We assumed zero R&D expenditure for low-income countries that do not report any data.
Imputation: We assumed zero R&D expenditure for low-income countries that did not report any data for this variable.

Indicator: Researchers (per 1,000 employed population)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The number of researchers per thousand employed people. Researchers are professionals engaged in the conception or creation of new knowledge, products, processes, methods and systems, as well as in the management of the projects concerned

Indicator: Triadic patent families filed (per million population)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: A triadic patent family is defined as a set of patents registered in various countries (i.e. patent offices) to protect the same invention. Triadic patent families are a set of patents filed at three of these major patent offices: the European Patent Office (EPO), the Japan Patent Office (JPO) and the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO). The number of triadic patent families is "nowcast" for timeliness.
Computation: This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of patents registered by total population and multiplying by 1 000 000.

Indicator: Gap in internet access by income (percentage points)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The difference in the percentage of household Internet access between the top and bottom income quartiles.
Imputation: Australia, Canada and the UK were assigned a missing value due to the lack of recent ICT usage surveys for households and individuals.
Computation: This indicator is calculated as the difference between the percentage of households in urban areas having access to internet and the percentage of households in rural areas having access to internet. When access to internet is higher in rural areas than in urban areas, the gap is noted as zero.

Indicator: Female share of graduates from STEM fields at the tertiary level (%)
Reference: World Bank (2023). Female share of graduates from Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) programmes, tertiary (%). World Bank, Washington, D.C. Available from: https://databank.worldbank.org/reports.aspx?source=283&series=SE.TER.GRAD.FE.SI.ZS
Description: Female share of graduates from Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) programs, tertiary (%)

Indicator: Gini coefficient
Reference: World Bank (2023). Gini index (World Bank estimate). World Bank, Washington, D.C. Available from: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SI.POV.GINI
Description: The Gini coefficient measures the extent to which the distribution of income among individuals or households within an economy deviates from a perfectly equal distribution.

Indicator: Palma ratio
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The share of all income received by the 10% people with highest disposable income divided by the share of all income received by the 40% people with the lowest disposable income.

Indicator: Elderly poverty rate (% of population aged 66 or over)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The percentage of people of 66 years of age or more whose income falls below half the median household income of the total population.

Indicator: Proportion of urban population living in slums (%)
Reference: UN Habitat (2023). Proportion of Urban Population Living in Slums. United Nations Human Settlements Programme, Nairoibi, Kenya. Available from: https://data.unhabitat.org/datasets/52c52084f31a403397e2c3bbee37f378_0/data
Description: Population living in slums is the proportion of the urban population living in slum households. A slum household is defined as a group of individuals living under the same roof lacking one or more of the following conditions: access to improved water, access to improved sanitation, sufficient living area, housing durability, and security of tenure.
Imputation: We assumed 0% population living in slums for high-income OECD members for which no data was reported.

Indicator: Annual mean concentration of particulate matter of less than 2.5 microns in diameter (PM2.5) (μg/m³)
Reference: IHME (2020). The Global Burden of Disease Study 2019. The Lancet, 17 October 2020, Volume 396, Issue 10258, Pages 1129-1306
Description: Air pollution measured as the population-weighted mean annual concentration of PM2.5 for the urban population in a country. PM2.5 is suspended particles measuring less than 2.5 microns in aerodynamic diameter, which are capable of penetrating deep into the respiratory tract and can cause severe health damage.

Indicator: Access to improved water source, piped (% of urban population)
Reference: WHO, UNICEF (2023). WHO / UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme: Data & estimates. World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Geneva and New York. Available from: https://washdata.org/data
Description: The percentage of the urban population with access to improved drinking water piped on premises. An "improved" drinking-water source is one that, by the nature of its construction and when properly used, adequately protects the source from outside contamination, particularly fecal matter.

Indicator: Satisfaction with public transport (%)
Reference: Gallup (2023). Gallup World Poll. https://www.gallup.com/analytics/318875/global-research.aspx
Description: The percentage of the surveyed population that responded "satisfied" to the question "In the city or area where you live, are you satisfied or dissatisfied with the public transportation systems?".

Indicator: Population with rent overburden (%)
Reference: Provisional data from the OECD Affordable Housing Database (http://www.oecd.org/housing/data/affordable-housing-database/), indicator HC1.2.
Description: Percentage of the population living in households where the total housing costs represent more than 40 % of disposable income.

Indicator: Proportion of population with access to points of interest within a 15min walk (%)
Source: SDSN (2023), based on Nicoletti, L., Sirenko, M., & Verma, T. (2023)
Reference: SDSN (2023) Pedestrian Accessibility Indicators by Country. Based on Nicoletti, L., Sirenko, M., & Verma, T. (2023). Disadvantaged communities have lower access to urban infrastructure. Environment and Planning B: Urban Analytics and City Science, 50(3), 831–849.
Description: The percentage of the population in urban areas living within 15-minute walking distance from a point of interest (i.e. hospitals, schools, supermarkets, restaurants, etc.) Distance is established through pedestrian street network data and the percentage of population in the radius is estimated using gridded population density.

Indicator: Municipal solid waste (kg/capita/day)
Reference: Kaza, Silpa; Yao, Lisa C.; Bhada-Tata, Perinaz; Van Woerden, Frank. 2018. What a Waste 2.0 : A Global Snapshot of Solid Waste Management to 2050. Urban Development;. Washington, DC: World Bank.
Description: The amount of waste collected by or on behalf of municipal authorities and disposed of through the waste management system. Waste from agriculture and from industries are not included.
Computation: This indicator is computed by multiplying the quantity of municipal solid waste in tons by 1000 to convert to kilos, by dividing by total population to obtain the annual waste per capita and dividing by 365 to express the volume in kg/capita/day.

Indicator: Electronic waste (kg/capita)
Reference: Forti V., Baldé C.P., Kuehr R., Bel G. The Global E-waste Monitor 2020: Quantities, flows and the circular economy potential. United Nations University (UNU)/United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR) – co-hosted SCYCLE Programme, International Telecommunication Union (ITU) & International Solid Waste Association (ISWA), Bonn/Geneva/Rotterdam.
Description: Waste from electrical and electronic equipment, estimated based on figures for domestic production, imports and exports of electronic products, as well as product lifespan data.

Indicator: Production-based SO₂ emissions (kg/capita)
Reference: Lenzen, M., Geschke, A., West, J., Fry, J., Malik, A., Giljum, S., Milà i Canals, L., Piñero, P., Lutter, S., Wiedmann, T., Li, M., Sevenster, M., Potočnik, J., Teixeira, I., Van Voore, M., Nansai, K. and Schandl, H. (2022) Implementing the material footprint to measure progress towards Sustainable Development Goals 8 and 12. Nature Sustainability, 5, 157-166. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41893-021-00811-6
Description: SO₂ emissions associated with the production of goods and services, which are then either exported or consumed domestically.
Computation: This indicator is obtained by multiplying production-based SO2 emissions in tonnes by 1 000 000 to obtain emissions in kilograms, and dividing by total population.

Indicator: SO₂ emissions embodied in imports (kg/capita)
Reference: Lenzen, M., Geschke, A., West, J., Fry, J., Malik, A., Giljum, S., Milà i Canals, L., Piñero, P., Lutter, S., Wiedmann, T., Li, M., Sevenster, M., Potočnik, J., Teixeira, I., Van Voore, M., Nansai, K. and Schandl, H. (2022) Implementing the material footprint to measure progress towards Sustainable Development Goals 8 and 12. Nature Sustainability, 5, 157-166. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41893-021-00811-6
Description: Emissions of SO₂ embodied in imported goods and services. SO₂ emissions have severe health impacts and are a significant cause of premature mortality worldwide.
Computation: This indicator is obtained by multiplying imported SO2 emissions in tonnes by 1 000 000 to obtain emissions in kilograms, and dividing by total population.

Indicator: Production-based nitrogen emissions (kg/capita)
New: Modification: now sourced from different Multi-regional input-output database, Gloria.
Reference: UNEP (2022). SCP-HAT database v2.0. http://scp-hat.lifecycleinitiative.org/methods/. UN Life Cycle Initiative, UN One Planet Network, UN International Resource Panel. Paris
Description: Reactive nitrogen emitted during the production of commodities, which are then either exported or consumed domestically. Reactive nitrogen corresponds to emissions of ammonia, nitrogen oxides and nitrous oxide to the atmosphere, and of reactive nitrogen potentially exportable to water bodies, all of which can be harmful to human health and the environment.
Computation: This indicator is obtained by multiplying production-based nitrogen emissions in tonnes by 1 000 000 000 to obtain emissions in kilograms, and dividing by total population.

Indicator: Nitrogen emissions embodied in imports (kg/capita)
New: Modification: now sourced from different Multi-regional input-output database, Gloria.
Reference: UNEP (2022). SCP-HAT database v2.0. http://scp-hat.lifecycleinitiative.org/methods/. UN Life Cycle Initiative, UN One Planet Network, UN International Resource Panel. Paris
Description: Emissions of reactive nitrogen embodied in imported goods and services. Reactive nitrogen corresponds here to emissions of ammonia, nitrogen oxides and nitrous oxide to the atmosphere, and of reactive nitrogen potentially exportable to water bodies, all of which can be harmful to human health and the environment.
Computation: This indicator is obtained by multiplying imported nitrogen emissions in tonnes by 1 000 000 000 to obtain emissions in kilograms, and dividing by total population.

Indicator: Exports of plastic waste (kg/capita)
Reference: UN Comtrade Database (2023). Available from: https://comtrade.un.org/data/
Description: The average annual amount of plastic waste exported over the last 5 years expressed per capita.
Computation: This indicator is computed as a 5-years average of exports of plastic waste (in kg), divided by total population.

Indicator: Non-recycled municipal solid waste (kg/capita/day)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The amount of municipal solid waste (MSW), including household waste, that is neither recycled nor composted.

Indicator: CO₂ emissions from fossil fuel combustion and cement production (tCO2/capita)
Reference: Friedlingstein, P., et al. (2020). Global Carbon Budget 2020, Earth Syst. Sci. Data, 2020. https://doi.org/10.5194/essd-12-3269-2020
Description: Emissions from the combustion and oxidation of fossil fuels and from cement production. The indicator excludes emissions from fuels used for international aviation and maritime transport.
Computation: This indicator is obtained by multiplying values in million tonnes of carbon per year (MtC) by 3.664, giving values in million tonnes of CO2 per year; then multiplied by 1 000 000 to obtain values in tonnes of CO2, which is then divided by total population to express it in tCO2 per capita.

Indicator: CO₂ emissions embodied in imports (tCO₂/capita)
Reference: Lenzen, M., Geschke, A., West, J., Fry, J., Malik, A., Giljum, S., Milà i Canals, L., Piñero, P., Lutter, S., Wiedmann, T., Li, M., Sevenster, M., Potočnik, J., Teixeira, I., Van Voore, M., Nansai, K. and Schandl, H. (2022) Implementing the material footprint to measure progress towards Sustainable Development Goals 8 and 12. Nature Sustainability, 5, 157-166. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41893-021-00811-6
Description: CO₂ emissions embodied in imported goods and services.
Computation: This indicator is obtained by multiplying kilotonnes of CO2 embodied in imports by 1 000 to convert into tonnes of CO2 (tCO2), divided by total population, to express it in tCO2 per capita.

Indicator: CO₂ emissions embodied in fossil fuel exports (kg/capita)
Reference: UN Comtrade Database (2023). Available from: https://comtrade.un.org/data/ WHO (2023). World Health Expenditure Database. World Health Organization, Geneva. Available from: http://apps.who.int/nha/database
Description: CO₂ emissions embodied in the exports of coal, gas, and oil. Calculated using a 5-year average of fossil fuel exports and converting exports into their equivalent CO₂ emissions. Exports for each fossil fuel are capped at the country's level of production.
Imputation: We assumed a value of 0 for countries with unreported export data and no production across all three fossil fuel types (coal, gas, oil). To avoid the biais of underreported export data, the top 40 producers of fossil fuels where exports represented less than 10% of national production are assigned missing.
Computation: This indicator is obtained by dividing CO2 emissions embodied in exports (kg) by total population.

Indicator: Carbon Pricing Score at EUR60/tCO₂ (%, worst 0-100 best)
Reference: OECD (2021), "Environmental policy: Effective carbon rates", OECD Environment Statistics (database), https://doi.org/10.1787/108c55c1-en
Description: The Carbon Pricing Score (CPS) measures the extent to which countries have attained the goal of pricing all energy related carbon emissions at certain benchmark values for carbon costs. The more progress that a country has made towards a specified benchmark value, the higher the CPS. For example, a CPS of 100% against a EUR 60 per tonne of CO2 benchmark means that the country (or the group of countries) prices all carbon emissions in its (their) territory from energy use at EUR 60 or more.

Indicator: Mean area that is protected in marine sites important to biodiversity (%)
Reference: BirdLife International, IUCN, UNEP-WCMC (2023). Resources and Data. BirdLife International, International Union for Conservation of Nature and United Nations Environment Programme - world Conservation Monitoring Center. Available from: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/
Description: The mean percentage area of marine Key Biodiversity Areas (sites that are important for the global persistence of marine biodiversity) that are protected.

Indicator: Ocean Health Index: Clean Waters score (worst 0-100 best)
Reference: Halpern BS, Longo C, Hardy D, McLeod KL, Samhouri JF, Katona SK, et al. (2012) An index to assess the health and benefits of the global ocean. Nature. 2012;488: 615–620.
Description: The clean waters subgoal of the Ocean Health Index measures to what degree marine waters under national jurisdictions have been contaminated by chemicals, excessive nutrients (eutrophication), human pathogens, and trash.

Indicator: Fish caught from overexploited or collapsed stocks (% of total catch)
Reference: Wolf, M. J., Emerson, J. W., Esty, D. C., de Sherbinin, A., Wendling, Z. A., et al. (2022). 2022 Environmental Performance Index. New Haven, CT: Yale Center for Environmental Law & Policy. epi.yale.edu
Description: The percentage of a country’s total catch, within its exclusive economic zone (EEZ), that is comprised of species that are overexploited or collapsed, weighted by the quality of fish catch data.

Indicator: Fish caught by trawling or dredging (%)
Reference: Pauly D, Zeller D, and Palomares M.L.D. (Editors) (2020) Sea Around Us Concepts, Design and Data (www.seaaroundus.org)
Description: The percentage of fish caught by bottom trawling, a method of fishing in which industrial fishing vessels drag large nets (trawls) along the seabed. This indicator is the sum of the series for bottom trawling, shrimp trawling, and dredging.
Computation: This indicator is calculated by summing the quantity (in tonnes) of fish caught by bottom trawling, shrimp trawling, and dredging, divided by the total catch (in tonnes). If the country is landlocked, the value is reported as missing; if not and data is missing the value is reported as 0.

Indicator: Fish caught that are then discarded (%)
Reference: Pauly D, Zeller D, and Palomares M.L.D. (Editors) (2020) Sea Around Us Concepts, Design and Data (www.seaaroundus.org)
Description: The percentage of fish that are caught only to be later discarded.
Computation: This indicator is computed by dividing the quantity of discarded fish (in tonnes) by the total catch (in tonnes). If the country is landlocked, the value is reported as missing; if not and data is missing the value is reported as 0.

Indicator: Marine biodiversity threats embodied in imports (per million population)
Source:
Lenzen et al. (2012) 
data updated to 2018
Reference: Lenzen, M., Moran, D., Kanemoto, K., Foran, B., Lobefaro, L., and Geschke, A. (2012). International trade drives biodiversity threats in developing nations, Nature, 486, 109-112. (Data-set updated to 2018 by Isaac Russell Peterson, Matthew Selinkske and colleagues). Available from: doi: 10.1038/nature11145
Description: Threats to marine species embodied in imports of goods and services.
Computation: This indicator is obtained by dividing imported marine biodiversity threats (animals and plants) by total population, and then multiplying by 1 000 000.

Indicator: Mean area that is protected in terrestrial sites important to biodiversity (%)
Reference: BirdLife International, IUCN, UNEP-WCMC (2023). Resources and Data. BirdLife International, International Union for Conservation of Nature and United Nations Environment Programme - world Conservation Monitoring Center. Available from: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/
Description: The mean percentage area of terrestrial Key Biodiversity Areas (sites that are important for the global persistence of biodiversity) that are protected.

Indicator: Mean area that is protected in freshwater sites important to biodiversity (%)
Reference: BirdLife International, IUCN, UNEP-WCMC (2023). Resources and Data. BirdLife International, International Union for Conservation of Nature and United Nations Environment Programme - world Conservation Monitoring Center. Available from: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/
Description: The mean percentage area of freshwater Key Biodiversity Areas (sites that are important for the global persistence of biodiversity) that are protected.

Indicator: Red List Index of species survival (worst 0-1 best)
Reference: IUCN, BirdLife International (2023). IUCN Red List. International Union for Conservation of Nature and Birdlife International. Available from: http://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/?indicator=15.5.1
Description: The change in aggregate extinction risk across groups of species. The index is based on genuine changes in the number of species in each category of extinction risk on The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species.

Indicator: Permanent deforestation (% of forest area, 3-year average)
Source:
Curtis et al. (2018) 
data updated to 2021
Reference: Curtis et al. (2018). Classifying drivers of global forest loss. Science, Vol. 361 - 6407, pp. 1108 - 1111. Data updated in 2020.
Description: The mean annual percentage of permanent deforestation over the last 3-year period. Permanent deforestation refers to tree cover removal for urbanization, commodity production and certain types of small-scale agriculture whereby the previous tree cover does not return. It does not include temporary forest loss due to cuttings within the forestry sector or wildfires. Since data on tree cover gains are not available, the annual net loss cannot be calculated, thus the indicator is an estimate for gross permanent deforestation.
Computation: For this indicator, we calculated the annual loss of tree cover as the sum of losses driven by exploitation for commodity production, urbanization, shifting agriculture, forestry or wildfires, and the permanent loss of tree cover as the sum of losses driven by exploitation for commodity production, urbanization and 50% of losses due to shifting agriculture. We calculated the annual extent of tree cover by substracting the annual loss of tree cover from the overall tree cover in 2010, and divided annual permanent loss by annual tree cover. The final indicator value is the three-year average of this ratio for years 2015, 2018 and 2021.

Indicator: Terrestrial and freshwater biodiversity threats embodied in imports (per million population)
Source:
Lenzen et al. (2012) 
data updated to 2018
Reference: Lenzen, M., Moran, D., Kanemoto, K., Foran, B., Lobefaro, L., and Geschke, A. (2012). International trade drives biodiversity threats in developing nations, Nature, 486, 109-112. (Data-set updated to 2018 by Isaac Russell Peterson, Matthew Selinkske and colleagues). Available from: doi: 10.1038/nature11145
Description: Threats to terrestrial and freshwater species embodied in imports of goods and services.
Computation: This indicator is obtained by summing imported freshwater biodiversity threats (animals and plants) and imported terrestrial biodiversity threats (animals and plants), and then dividing by total population. This is subsequently multiplied by 1 000 000.

Indicator: Homicides (per 100,000 population)
Reference: UNODC (2023). Global Study on Homicides. United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, Vienna. Available from: https://dataunodc.un.org/GSH_app
Description: The number of intentional homicides per 100,000 people. Intentional homicides are estimates of unlawful homicides purposely inflicted as a result of domestic disputes, interpersonal violence, violent conflicts over land resources, intergang violence over turf or control, and predatory violence and killing by armed groups. Intentional homicide does not include all intentional killing, such as killing in armed conflict.

Indicator: Unsentenced detainees (% of prison population)
Reference: UNODC (2023). Prisons & Prisoners. United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, Vienna. Available from https://dataunodc.un.org/dp-prisons-persons-held
Description: Unsentenced prisoners as a percentage of overall prison population. Persons held unsentenced or pre-trial refers to persons held in prisons, penal institutions or correctional institutions who are untried, pre-trial or awaiting a first instance decision on their case from a competent authority regarding their conviction or acquittal.

Indicator: Population who feel safe walking alone at night in the city or area where they live (%)
Reference: Gallup (2023). Gallup World Poll. https://www.gallup.com/analytics/318875/global-research.aspx
Description: The percentage of the surveyed population that responded "Yes" to the question "Do you feel safe walking alone at night in the city or area where you live?"

Indicator: Birth registrations with civil authority (% of children under age 5)
Reference: UNICEF (2023). Birth registration. United Nations Children's Fund, New York. Available from: http://data.unicef.org/topic/child-protection/birth-registration/
Description: The percentage of children under the age of five whose births are reported as being registered with the relevant national civil authorities.

Indicator: Corruption Perceptions Index (worst 0-100 best)
Reference: Transparency International (2022). Corruption Perceptions Index 2022. Transparency International, Berlin. Available from:  https://www.transparency.org/en/cpi/
Description: The perceived levels of public sector corruption, on a scale from 0 (highest level of perceived corruption) to 100 (lowest level of perceived corruption). The CPI aggregates data from a number of different sources that provide perceptions of business people and country experts.

Indicator: Children involved in child labor (% of population aged 5 to 14)
Reference: UNICEF (2023). Child Labour. Available from: http://data.unicef.org/topic/child-protection/child-labour/
Description: The percentage of children, between the age of 5 and 14 years old, involved in child labor at the time of the survey. A child is considered to be involved in child labor under the following conditions: (a) children 5-11 years old who, during the reference week, did at least one hour of economic activity or at least 28 hours of household chores, or (b) children 12-14 years old who, during the reference week, did at least 14 hours of economic activity or at least 28 hours of household chores. We assumed 0% child labor for high-income countries for which no data was reported.
Imputation: The best performing upper-middle-income countries have a child labor rate of 1% (UNICEF, 2015). We assumed 0% child labor for high-income OECD members for which no data was reported.

Indicator: Exports of major conventional weapons (TIV constant million USD per 100,000 population)
Reference: SIPRI (2023). SIPRI Arms Transfers Database. Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, Stockholm. Available from: https://www.sipri.org/ databases/armstransfers.
Description: Volume of major conventional weapons exported, expressed in constant 1990 US$ millions (TIV) per 100,000 population. The trend-indicator value is based on the known unit production cost of a core set of weapons and does not reflect the financial value of the exports. Small arms, light weapons, ammunition and other support material are not included. Values were calculated using a 5-year average on the latest ten years of data. *The inclusion of an indicator on the exports of major conventional weapons should not be interpreted as a value judgment by the authors on the policies implemented in the context of the war in Ukraine.
Computation: This indicator is calculated as the 5-year average exports of major conventional weapons (TIV constant 1990 million USD), divided by total population, multiplied by 100 000.

Indicator: Press Freedom Index (worst 0-100 best)
Reference: Reporters sans frontières (2023). World Press Freedom Index 2023. Available from: https://rsf.org/en/ranking
Description: Degree of freedom available to journalists in 180 countries and regions, determined by pooling the responses of experts to a questionnaire devised by RSF.

Indicator: Access to and affordability of justice (worst 0–1 best)
Reference: The World justice project : Rule of Law Index 2022. Washington, D.C: The World Justice Project, 2022. Available from: https://worldjusticeproject.org/rule-of-law-index/
Description: Measures the accessibility and affordability of civil courts, including whether people are aware of available remedies; can access and afford legal advice and representation; and can access the court system without incurring unreasonable fees, encountering unreasonable procedural hurdles, or experiencing physical or linguistic barriers.

Indicator: Timeliness of administrative proceedings (worst 0 - 1 best)
Reference: The World justice project : Rule of Law Index 2022. Washington, D.C: The World Justice Project, 2022. Available from: https://worldjusticeproject.org/rule-of-law-index/
Description: Measures whether administrative proceedings at the national and local levels are conducted without unreasonable delay.

Indicator: Expropriations are lawful and adequately compensated (worst 0 - 1 best)
Reference: The World justice project : Rule of Law Index 2022. Washington, D.C: The World Justice Project, 2022. Available from: https://worldjusticeproject.org/rule-of-law-index/
Description: Measures whether the government respects the property rights of people and corporations, refrains from the illegal seizure of private property, and provides adequate compensation when property is legally expropriated.

Indicator: Persons held in prison (per 100,000 population)
Reference: UNODC (2023). Prisons & Prisoners. United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, Vienna. Available from https://dataunodc.un.org/dp-prisons-persons-held
Description: The prison population is composed of persons held in prisons, penal institutions, or correctional institutions.

Indicator: Government spending on health and education (% of GDP)
Reference: UNESCO (2023). Government expenditure on education. United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Paris. Available from: http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.XPD.TOTL.GD.ZS. WHO (2023). World Health Expenditure Database. World Health Organization, Geneva. Available from: http://apps.who.int/nha/database
Description: The sum of public expenditure on health from domestic sources and general government expenditure on education (current, capital, and transfers) expressed as a percentage of GDP. This indicator is based on the World Bank health and education spending datasets, sourced from WHO & UNESCO respectively. Values are carried forward for both health and education, but a value in a given year is only reported if at least one data point is a real observation (not carried forward).

Indicator: For high-income and all OECD DAC countries: International concessional public finance, including official development assistance (% of GNI)
Reference: OECD (2023). OECD Statistics. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paris. Available from: http://stats.oecd.org/
Description: The amount of official development assistance (ODA) as a share of gross national income (GNI). It includes grants, "soft" loans (where the grant element is at least 25% of the total) and the provision of technical assistance and excludes grants and loans for military purposes. There is a break in the series because from 2019, the ODA grant-equivalent methodology is used whereby only the “grant portion” of the loan, i.e. the amount “given” by lending below market rates, counts as ODA.

Indicator: Other countries: Government revenue excluding grants (% of GDP)
Reference: International Monetary Fund (2023). Government Finance Statistics Yearbook. Available from: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/GC.REV.XGRT.GD.ZS?view=chart
Description: Government revenue measured as cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Grants are also considered as revenue but are excluded here.
Imputation: IMF data (taxes, social contributions, and other revenue, excluding grants) is imputed when countries are missing data in the World Bank database. The IMF data used is from the central government (incl. social security funds) sector. If that is not available, we use data for the budgetary central government sector.

Indicator: Corporate Tax Haven Score (best 0-100 worst)
Reference: Ates L., Cobham A., Harari M., Janský P., Meinzer M., Millan-Narotzky L., Palanský M. 2021. The Corporate Tax Haven Index: A New Geography of Profit Shifting. In B. Unger, L. Russel, J. Ferwerda (Eds.), Combatting Fiscal Fraud and Empowering Regulators. Oxford, UK: Oxford University Press.
Description: The Corporate Tax Haven Score measures a jurisdiction’s potential to poach the tax base of others, as enshrined in its laws, regulations and documented administrative practices. For countries with multiple jurisdictions, the average value across the jurisdictions was assigned to the country.
Imputation: A value of 0 was imputed to all countries not included in the index. Missing data was assigned to those countries not included in the index and indicated in the OECD Automatic Exchange of Information Implementation Report 2018 (Nauru, Qatar & Bahrain). According to the report, these countries have no system for direct taxation in place and do not have reciprocal information-exchanges.

Indicator: Financial Secrecy Score (best 0-100 worst)
Reference: Tax Justice Network (2020). Financial Secrecy Index 2020. Tax Justice Network, London. Available from: https://www.financialsecrecyindex.com/introduction/fsi-2018-results
Description: The Index measures the contribution of each jurisdiction to financial secrecy, on a scale from 0 (best) to 100 (worst). It is calculated using qualitative data to prepare a secrecy score for each jurisdiction and quantitative data to create a global scale weighting for each jurisdiction according to its share of offshore financial services activity in the global total. For countries with multiple jurisdictions, the average score of the jurisdictions was used.

Indicator: Shifted profits of multinationals (US$ billion)
Reference: Zucman, G. et al. (2019). The Missing Profits of Nations: 2016 Figures. Available from: https://missingprofits.world
Description: Estimation of how much profit is shifted into tax havens and how much non-haven countries lose in profits from such shifting. Based on macroeconomic data known as foreign affiliates statistics. Negative values indicate profit shifting.

Indicator: Statistical Performance Index (worst 0-100 best)
Reference: World Bank (2023). Statistical Performance Indicators, SPI Overall Score. World Bank, Washington D.C., Available from: https://databank.worldbank.org/Statistical-Performance-Indicators-(SPI)/id/c6cc9909
Description: The Statistical Performance Index is a weighted average of the statistical performance indicators that evaluate the performance of national statistical systems. It aggregates five pillars of statistical performance: data use, data services, data products, data sources, and data infrastructure.
